Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The role of floral secondary compounds in bee performance and disease transmission in a natural ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural chemical defenses occur in all plants and can be toxic to animals that eat plants (herbivores). Interestingly, some herbivores are able to eat and then use these naturally-occurring chemicals to protect themselves from predators and parasites. Because bees consume large amounts of nectar and pollen that contain these chemicals, they may be able use them as a form of self-medication. This work will test that idea. The research has three main objectives: (1) Pollen and nectar will be collected from wild plant species and tested for potentially protective chemicals. This will reveal the extent to which bees are naturally exposed to such chemicals. (2) Laboratory experiments will determine which chemicals may affect disease in bees. (3) Laboratory and field experiments will test the role of the same chemicals on disease transmission between flowers and bees. Taken together, this research represents a novel approach and will provide insight into how plant defensive chemicals can impact wild animals.

This work also addresses the contemporary societal issue of bee health and disease. Many bee populations are in steep decline, which poses a large threat to society because bees provide pollination services that are essential for plant conservation and crop production -- services that are worth billions of dollars annually in the United States. While the combination of many factors is responsible for the crash of bee populations, diseases are one of the major culprits. Understanding whether bees can use particular compounds in nectar and pollen to self-medicate has great potential for discovery of new mechanisms to manage bee diseases and combat pollinator decline. Finally, by training students in bee ecology, this project will help produce a new generation of scientists with the skills needed to pursue solutions to bee decline and other ecological threats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pollinators provide billions of dollars in crop pollination annually, and are key components preserving plant biodiversity in native ecosystems. Animal pollination is necessary for the production of 35% of the global food supply, and pollinators are essential for the production of at least 90 major crops in the United States. In the last decade, there have been mounting concerns about declines in both managed and wild bees. Although a variety of factors may be involved, parasites have been strongly implicated in the declines. Nectar and pollen are the primary food items of the majority of bees, but in addition to sugars and protein, these food sources also frequently contain plant chemical defenses. These compounds often reduce parasitism for insects that eat plants, but their impacts on bee pollinators are almost entirely unknown.

The goals of this research were to (1) conduct an ambitious, broad survey of chemical defenses in pollen and nectar, (2) test the costs and benefits of nectar and pollen secondary compounds on bees in the presence and absence of parasites, and (3) determine the role of floral traits, including chemical defenses, in disease transmission dynamics. The work focuses on two important common pollinators, bumble bees (Bombus impatiens) and honey bees (Apis mellifera), and their parasites.

We found an incredible diversity of chemical defenses in pollen and nectar, identifying over 100 compounds from a wide range of plant species. This suggests that bees are regularly exposed to many chemical defenses with unknown consequences for their health. There was little overlap in the chemistry of pollen and nectar. Pollen typically had 20- to 200 times more concentrated defenses than nectar, and 60% more different compounds. Although our preliminary data found consistent effects of several nectar chemical defenses in reducing a pathogen in bumble bees, follow up experiments produced inconsistent results, suggesting that the effect of nectar chemicals on pathogens may depend on the pathogen strain or bee colony. In the course of this work, we also compared the effect of three different pollens on the same pathogen, and found that sunflower pollen dramatically and consistently reduced this pathogen. Furthermore, bumble bees from farms with more sunflower had lower pathogen infection. Sunflower pollen did not reduce performance of bumble bees, but was detrimental to honey bee survival, even though it also reduced infection by a honey bee pathogen. This suggests that sunflowers may provide options for pollinator plantings and colony supplements for chemical-free methods of reducing pathogens in bumble bees; we will evaluate this further in future work. Finally, we found that the extent of disease transmission varied four-fold depending on what plant species bumble bees were foraging on, although very few floral traits actually predicted which plant species transmitted a lot or little pathogen. We manipulated both the number of flowers and a nectar chemical defense in flowers, and neither significantly affected transmission. Nonetheless, our result that pathogen transmission differs with plant species suggests that the species we choose to plant in pollinator habitat may have consequences for disease transmission dynamics.

This grant provided research opportunities for more than 40 undergraduates and post-graduates, 5 high school students, and 3 graduate students. Several undergraduates and one graduate student were first-generation students. Several of the high school participants are now enrolled in top universities, including Harvard, Brown/RISD and Vanderbilt, and several of the undergraduate participants are now in graduate school, medical school, or pursuing careers in science. Many students had the opportunity to conduct and publish their own research; to date this proposal has resulted in 6 manuscripts submitted or published with undergraduate first authors, and two more with undergraduate co-authors. We also conveyed research outcomes to the general public through several venues, including talks at beekeeper meetings, bee festivals, grower meetings, school programs, and hosting middle-school girls from an underserved community via the Eureka! program.
